choices.text: The median nerve of the right hand is injured.
There is weakness of thenar muscles on the right side
The adductor pollicis of the right side is weak
The flexor muscles of the thumb of the right hand is weak

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents to the orthopedic clinic with complaints of progressive weakness in his right hand. The patient reports difficulty in fine movements of hand. Doctor performed a test over patient as shown in image. Which of the following statements is true about the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The adductor pollicis of the right side is weak

 

Option C:

 

  • Patient is having difficulty in fine movement of the hand which clearly indicates that this question is about the ulnar nerve. Because the ulnar nerve is considered as the nerve which is responsible for fine movements since it supplies 15 out of 20 muscles of the hand.
  • The above image shows Froment’s sign/ Book test/ Adductor Pollicis Test.
  • At thenar eminence the adductor pollicis muscle is supplied by ulnar nerve and the test shown in the image is checking the adductor muscle of thumb (thenar eminence) hence in turn it is checking the ulnar nerve.
  • Due to an injury of the ulnar nerve the patient is unable to adduct his thumb.
  • All the thenar muscles are supplied by the median nerve except adductor pollicis which is supplied by the ulnar nerve.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The median nerve is not injured as the inability to adduct the thumb is due to injury to the ulnar nerve.

 

Option B. The thenar muscles are innervated by the median nerve. Hence no weakness of thenar muscles on the right side will be found because damaged nerve in this case is ulnar nerve.

 

Option D. The flexor pollicis brevis muscles is supplied by the median nerve and flexor pollicis longus is supplied by the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve in the forearm. So, they are not weak on the right side.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The adductor pollicis is innervated by a deep branch of the ulnar nerve and causes adduction of the thumb. The patient is unable to adduct his thumb due to paralysis of adductor pollicis which is supplied by the ulnar nerve. He tries to hold the book by flexing his thumb.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, upper limb and thorax, Vishram Singh, 3rd edition, pg. 131

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with weakness in his right hand and difficulty extending his fingers and wrist. Physical examination reveals intact sensation but significant weakness in wrist and finger extension on the affected side. He recently had a fall and sustained a forearm injury. Which of the following muscles is most likely affected in this patient's condition, and which nerve is responsible for its innervation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Extensor Digitorum

 

Option D:

 

  • Among given option only Extensor digitorum is muscle of posterior compartment of forearm.
  • Posterior compartment of forearm muscles are supplied by Radial nerve or its deep branch (PIN)
  • Deep branch of radial nerve is known as Posterior Interosseous Nerve (PIN)
  • Radial nerve & its different branches shown in image

 

 

  • From image it is clear that PIN supplies all muscles of posterior compartment of forearm except 3 muscles (ABE):
    • A-  Anconeus
    • B-  Brachioradialis
    • E-  ECRL

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Flexor digitorum superficialis is innervated by the median nerve.

 

Option B. Pronator quadratus is innervated by the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve.

 

Option C. Brachioradialis is innervated by the radial nerve before termination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Extensor digitorum in the posterior compartment of the forearm is innervated by the posterior interosseous nerve.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 101

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of weakness and clumsiness in their hand, particularly involving the ulnar-sided fingers. The physician is evaluating for possible ulnar nerve injury and discusses various diagnostic tests during the examination. Which of the following tests is NOT typically used to detect ulnar nerve injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pen Test

 

Option C:

 

  • Pen Test is another method used to evaluate ulnar nerve function. 
  • Patient is asked to touch the pen using the thumb, which in turn test the thenar muscles (mainly abductor pollicis brevis) supplied by the median nerve.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Egawa Test is less commonly referenced and not a standard test for ulnar nerve functions. It's not typically associated with the assessment of ulnar nerve injury.

 

Option D. Froment's Sign is a clinical test specifically used to identify ulnar nerve palsy. The test involves asking the patient to grip a piece of paper between the thumb and index finger. If the patient flexes the thumb’s distal phalanx (due to weakness in the adductor pollicis, which is innervated by the ulnar nerve), it indicates a positive Froment's sign.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Card Test is used to assess the function of the palmar interossei muscles, which are innervated by the ulnar nerve. The test involves holding a card between two fingers (other than the thumb) and can reveal weakness in these muscles, indicating potential ulnar nerve injury.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 165

questions.text: A 20-year-old male fractured his left tibia in a motor bike accident. His left leg was fixed in a cast and he used crutches for ambulation. Two weeks later, he had difficulty in extending his wrist. Which nerve is most probably injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radial Nerve

 

Option B:

 

  •  In this case, due to prolong use of crutches, injury to radial nerve in axilla took place
  • The radial nerve supplies the muscles in the posterior aspect of the arm and forearm which are extensors of the upper limb.
  • This condition is known as crutch palsy or saturday night palsy
    Clinical Features include :
  1. Loss of extension of elbow - due to paralysis of triceps
  2. Loss of extension of wrist - Due to unopposed action of flexors of forearm
  3. Loss of extension of digits - due to paralysis of extensor digitorum, extensor indices, extensor digiti minimi, extensor pollicis longus
  4. Loss of supination in extended elbow - supinator and brachioradialis are paralysed
  5. Sensory loss over posterior surface of lower part of arm, forearm
  6. Sensory loss of lateral half of dorsum of hand
     
  • Injury to the radial nerve can lead to wrist drop, a condition characterized by difficulty in extending the wrist and fingers.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.

 

  • Long Thoracic Nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which is crucial for stabilizing the scapula. Damage to this nerve can lead to winging of the scapula, but it would not affect wrist extension. Damage to Long thoracic nerve leads to winging of scapula.

 

Option C.

 

  • Musculocutaneous Nerve innervates muscles in the anterior compartment of the arm, like the biceps brachii, and is involved in flexing the elbow.
  • Damage to the musculocutaneous nerve would lead to weakness in elbow flexion and a diminished sensation in the lateral forearm.

 

Option D.

 

  • Median Nerve innervates most of the muscles of the anterior compartment of the forearm and some muscles in the hand.
  • It is primarily involved in flexing the wrist and fingers and providing sensation to the palmar side of the hand.
  • Injury to the median nerve would lead to problems with wrist and finger flexion and sensory deficits in the hand, but not difficulty in extending the wrist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Radial Nerve innervates the muscles in the posterior compartment of the forearm, which are responsible for extending the wrist and fingers.
  • Injury to the radial nerve can lead to wrist drop, a condition characterized by difficulty in extending the wrist and fingers. 
  • Given the patient's symptoms and the use of crutches, which can compress the radial nerve in the axillary region (crutch palsy), this is the most likely injured nerve.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st edition, pg no. 832

choices.text: Sensory loss on dorsum of first web space
Loss of supination in extended position

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents to the emergency department after sustaining a laceration to the wrist in a work-related accident. On examination, the patient exhibits difficulty extending the wrist and fingers. There is also a noticeable loss of sensation in the dorsum of the hand, specifically in the first web space. Which of the following clinical findings is most likely associated with injury to the radial nerve at the wrist?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sensory loss on dorsum of first web space

 

Option B:

 

  • In this case radial nerve injury at wrist has been mentioned hence only sensory loss will be seen.
  • Radial nerve terminates at the level of lateral epicondyle by dividing into superficial and deep branches (PIN).
  • Injury to the superficial branch at the wrist leads to sensory loss on the dorsum of the first web space.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.

 

  • Wrist Drop is caused by paralysis of the wrist extensors, which are primarily innervated by the PIN.
  • However, for wrist drop to occur, the radial nerve injury would typically need to be at or above the elbow, where the nerve innervates the extensor muscles of the forearm.
  • An injury at the wrist level usually does not cause wrist drop because the motor branches to the extensors have already branched off from the radial nerve proximally.

 

Option C.

 

  • The adductor pollicis muscle is involved in the adduction of the thumb and is innervated by the ulnar nerve, not the radial nerve.
  • An injury to the radial nerve, regardless of the location, would not typically cause paralysis of the adductor pollicis.

 

Option D.

 

  • Supination of the forearm is primarily performed by the biceps brachii and the supinator muscle.
  • The biceps brachii is innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve, and the supinator muscle is innervated by the radial nerve. 
  • While the radial nerve does innervate the supinator muscle, its branch to this muscle is given off higher up in the arm, not at the wrist. Therefore, an injury to the radial nerve at the wrist level is unlikely to significantly impact supination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sensory Loss on Dorsum of First Web Space:

 

  • The radial nerve provides sensory innervation to the dorsum of the hand, including the first web space between the thumb and index finger.
  •  An injury to the radial nerve at the wrist level would affect its sensory function, potentially causing sensory loss in this area.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 168

choices.text: Card Test is done to test for contraction of Dorsal Interossei
Hypothenar Muscles arise from Pisiform and Hamate
Palmaris Brevis is remnant of Panniculus Carnosus

questions.text: A patient suffering from Hansen’s disease had burnt his left hand unintentionally. The physician on examination noted loss of sensation in medial one and half fingers and medial side of palmar and dorsal aspects of left hand. In addition, there was flattening of hypothenar eminence and difficulty in holding a card between thumb and index finger. Identify the incorrect statement pertaining to the above scenario:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Card test is done to test for contraction of Dorsal Interossei

 

Option B:

 

  • Card test is done to test for palmar interossei which causes adduction of digits.
  • The card test is actually used to assess the function of the palmar interossei muscles, which are responsible for adducting the fingers and are innervated by the ulnar nerve. The dorsal interossei, responsible for finger abduction, are not specifically tested by the card test.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.

 

  • The symptoms of loss of sensation in the medial one and a half fingers and the medial side of the hand, along with flattening of the hypothenar eminence, are indicative of ulnar nerve injury or impairment.
  • The ulnar nerve innervates the hypothenar muscles and provides sensation to this area of the hand.

 

Option C.

 

  • The Hypothenar muscles, which include the Abductor Digiti Minimi, Flexor Digiti Minimi Brevis, and Opponens Digiti Minimi, indeed have origins involving the pisiform and the hook of the hamate.
  • These muscles contribute to movements of the little finger and are innervated by the ulnar nerve.

 

Option D.

 

  • Palmaris Brevis is a small muscle in the hand that is considered a remnant of the panniculus carnosus, an extensive sheet of muscle found in many mammals.
  • In humans, only a few remnants of this muscle group remain, including the palmaris brevis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Card Test is done to Test for Contraction of Dorsal Interosseous: The card test is actually used to assess the function of the palmar interossei muscles, which are responsible for adducting the fingers and are innervated by the ulnar nerve. The dorsal interossei, responsible for finger abduction, are not specifically tested by the card test.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st edition, pg no. 893

choices.text: It passes deep to the flexor retinaculum
In the lower half of forearm it has a subfascial course
It enters the palm on the radial side of pisiform bone
In the lower half, it  lies superficial and lateral to flexor carpi ulnaris.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about the nerve involved in causing the deformity in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It passes deep to the flexor retinaculum

 

Option A:

 

  • The deformity shown in the above image is “Medial Claw Hand”
  • It is caused due to injury to the ulnar nerve.
  • Ulnar nerve passes superficial to the flexor retinaculum as shown in image below:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Ulnar nerve is deeply placed in the proximal part of the forearm, whereas in the distal forearm, it has a subfascial course.

 

Option C. Ulnar nerve is accompanied by ulnar artery that enters the palm on the radial side of the pisiform bone.

 

Option D. The nerve enters the forearm by passing between the two heads of flexor carpi ulnaris. In the upper third of forearm, it runs almost vertically downwards under flexor carpi ulnaris. In the lower two-third of the forearm, it becomes superficial and lies lateral to the flexor carpi ulnaris. In this part of its course the ulnar nerve and artery descend together, artery being on the lateral side of the nerve.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ulnar nerve does not pass deep to the flexor retinaculum. Instead, it travels superficial to the flexor retinaculum, entering the hand via Guyon's canal, a space different from the carpal tunnel where the median nerve and flexor tendons pass under the flexor retinaculum.

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, upper limb and thorax, Vishram Singh, 3rd edition, pg. 110
